title.rendered: Find Rooms for Rent in Huntington Beach

content.rendered:
Looking for the safest neighborhoods to find rooms for rent in Huntington Beach? Or to learn how to get around the city? Roomi’s city guide has the info you need to ensure a great time when moving to a new city!

Get to Know Huntington Beach

Dog-friendly beaches, parks, and pleasant weather… what else could you want when moving to a new city? Every year, tons of people hope to find affordable rooms for rent in Huntington Beach, close to the beach. And although living in the city can be expensive, it has plenty to offer.

With numerous parks, restaurants, cafés, and over 11 miles of beach, living in Huntington Beach seems like a vacation. Although most of the year is sunny, the sun is scorching. Overall, the city has a laidback vibe, with a perfect blend of urban and suburban lifestyles.

Related: How to Manage Expenses while Coliving

Finding cheap rooms for rent in Huntington Beach

Find A Room For Rent In Huntington Beach, CA

Hoping to find cheap rooms for rent in Huntington Beach? You might have to search for a while. The average rent in Huntington Beach can be high, and it is one of the most expensive cities to live in. As with any city, the neighborhood you live in matters a lot when it comes to monthly expenses.

Most people in the city rent their homes, so the market can be competitive. Keep travel costs and safety in mind when you’re selecting rooms for rent in Huntington Beach.

Related: How To Stick To The Personal Budget You Make

Top neighborhoods for rooms for rent in Huntington Beach

Huntington Beach is divided into several neighborhoods, which have distinct vibes. Depending on whether you’re looking for cheap rooms for rent in Huntington Beach for yourself, or for your family, you’ll find a neighborhood that suits your tastes.

  • Sunset Beach: If you could condense Huntington Beach to just one neighborhood, it would be Sunset Beach. It embodies the laid-back vibe of the city. There are plenty of self-guided walking tours perfect for newbies who want to discover the city. Additionally, it is close to the Pacific Coast Highway, with plenty of shopping and dining options.
  • Bolsa Chica: Home of the Bolsa Chica State Beach and the Bolsa Chica Ecological Reserve, this neighborhood is for those who love nature. The Bolsa Chica State Beach is one of few parks in the city that allows bonfires, which are perfect for making new friends! Here, the waves are much calmer, offering you the perfect opportunity to work on your surfing hobby.
  • Downtown: For those who want to be close to the heart of the city, either for work or entertainment, Downtown Huntington Beach is the best option. Here, you’ll find a popular neighborhood close to the Huntington Beach Pier, clubs, and popular restaurants.

Average rent in Huntington Beach

University life in Huntington Beach

As a student, you’ll have to prepare to commute every day from Huntington Beach. As most colleges are located outside the city, you’ll want to opt for on-campus housing. If you plan to commute every day, these are the best neighborhoods to have fun chilling at the beach with your friends or exploring all the city has to offer.

Related: What You Should Know About Living with Roommates in College

Universities close to Huntington Beach to check out are:

  • University of California-Irvine
  • University of Southern California

How transit-friendly is Huntington Beach?

The Transportation Division of the Department of Public Works provides a safe and efficient transportation system in Huntington Beach. There are plenty of opportunities to walk around neighborhoods, go on drives, or even hop on a bike. While most commuters prefer to drive, alternate commute options are available.

1. Walkability

With a walk score of 55, Huntington Beach has average walkability. Depending on where you find rooms for rent in Huntington Beach, you can enjoy exploring the city on foot. Some of the most walkable neighborhoods in the city are Downtown, Oak View, and Yorktown.

2. Roads/traffic

The average one-way commute time in this city is 28.9 minutes, which is slightly higher than the national average. Driving is the preferred commute option, followed by carpooling. Only 1.1% of commuters opt for public transit, as more people prefer to bike or walk. While other cities may have worse traffic, you should try to find rooms for rent in Huntington Beach close to your workplace. Traffic can pile up fast!

Major highways in the city include the Pacific Coast Highway, which connects the beach cities throughout California; the San Diego Freeway, which connects with all other major freeways in Southern California; and the Beach Boulevard, which runs directly through the heart of the city.

3. Taxis

Numerous taxi services are available in Huntingtin Beach, including Uber and Lyft. Fares start from $3.50, with an additional $2.75 for every additional mile and a waiting fee of $32 per hour.

4. Public transportation

While only a few commuters opt for public transportation, there are still some options available. The Orange Country Transportation Authority provides nine bus routes on its regional bus service. Additionally, Trailways and Greyhound are the two other major bus route providers in the city.

5. Airports

The closest airport to the city is the John Wayne Airport in Santa Ana. For those flying via JetBlue Airways, the Long Beach Airport will be the best option. However, if you’re still looking for more options, you can opt for the Los Angeles International Airport.

6. Cycling

Huntington Beach has over 10 miles of paved biking paths near the beach, offering the most beautiful views. Actually, the city is quite bike-friendly, with plenty of bike rental services as well. Although several roads have proper bike infrastructure, cyclists should still bike with caution in mind.

Restaurants near rooms for rent in Huntington Beach

What’s the best way to learn more about a new city? Exploring the food scene and discovering local favorites, of course! Here are the places you should check out:

  • Secret Spot: Perfect for those who want flavorful and healthy food.
  • The Black Trumpet Bistro: Intended for those who want to explore Mediterranean cuisine in the city.
  • Slapfish: This restaurant not only specializes in American seafood but is also committed to providing healthy and sustainable menu items.

Cultural Activities in Huntington Beach

Whether you have friends over or you just want to explore this new city at your own pace, Huntington Beach has plenty to see! For instance, Huntington Beach residents pride themselves on the number of beaches and parks throughout the city.

Here’s where to look for the best places to visit:

  • Huntington Beach Pier
  • Huntington Central Park
  • Bolsa Chica Ecological Reserve

Do you know what else Roomi does outside of helping its readers find rooms for rent in Huntington Beach? With our ever-increasing lists of rooms and roommates across the world, we help you find your perfect match! 

DOWNLOAD THE APP NOW!
